Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Frieda Schwenkmeyer Collection on the Henry Street Settlement Strike
Schwenkmeyer, Frieda
WAG.147
1 Linear Feet in 1 record carton
1963-1993 1965 Frieda Schwenkmeyer (1901- ) was a labor organizer from Cincinnati, Ohio. In 1965 the Henry Street Settlement social workers went on strike for over two months, demanding a single bargaining unit encompassing all workers. This collection contains correspondence, flyers, petitions, meeting notes, picket schedules, clippings, and a small amount of financial records. Materials are in English
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Henry Street Settlement Strike Records; WAG 147; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number 1950.258 is associated with this collection.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives has no information about copyright ownership for this collection and is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from it. Materials in this collection, which were created in 1963-1993, are expected to enter the public domain in 2114.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Historical/Biographical Note
Frieda Schwenkmeyer (1901- ) was a labor organizer from Cincinnati, Ohio. Over the course of her career Schwenkmeyer worked for the YWCA, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, the United Electrical Workers and the Henry Street Settlement.
The Henry Street Settlement is a social service agency located in the Lower East Side, which was founded by Lillian Wald in 1893. The Settlement provides social services, arts programming and health care to New Yorkers at 17 difference locations. In 1965 the Henry Street Settlement social workers went on strike for over two months, demanding a single bargaining unit encompassing all workers (both permanent staff and special project staff employeed through foundation or government funding).
Scope and Content Note
This collection contains correspondence, flyers, petitions, meeting notes, picket schedules, clippings, and a small amount of financial records.
Processing Information
Loose materials were placed in archival folders. Folder titles are original to the donor, except those in square brackets, which have been supplied by the archivist.
